title: Which graph of force vs. distance shows fastest

content.question: A student uses a spring scale to exert a horizontal force on a block, pulling the block over a smooth floor. The student repeats the procedure several times, each time pulling the block from rest through a distance of 1.0 m. For which of the following graphs of force as a function of distance will the block be moving the fastest at the end of the 1.0 m?

choices.label: The figure presents a graph of a line in the first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled “Distance, in meters,” and the numbers 0 through 1 point 0, in increments of 0 point 5, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled “Force, in newtons,” and the numbers 0 through 6 point 0, in increments of 3 point 0, are indicated. The line begins at 3 point 0 newtons and 0 meters, and moves horizontally, ending at 3 point 0 newtons at 1 point 0 meter.
The figure presents a graph of a segmented line in the first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled

The figure presents a graph of a line in the first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled Distance, in meters, and the numbers 0 through 1 point 0, in increments of 0 point 5, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled Force, in newtons, and the numbers 0 through 6 point 0, in increments of 3 point 0, are indicated. The line begins at 0 newtons at 0 meters, and then moves steadily upward and to the right, ending at 6 point 0 newtons at 1 point 0 meter.

The figure presents a graph of a line in the first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled Distance, in meters, and the numbers 0 through 1 point 0, in increments of 0 point 5, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled Force, in newtons, and the numbers 0 through 6 point 0, in increments of 3 point 0, are indicated. The line begins at 6 point 0 newtons at 0 meters, and then moves steadily downward and to the right, until it reaches 3 point 0 newtons at 0 point 5 meter. It then moves horizontally, until it ends at 3 point 0 newtons at 1 point 0 meter.
